Hi Thu, Dung. Nice work so far, though I have a few suggestions to improve the safety.
If you address my comments on the previous patch this will need some rework.
Updated.
This is condition is tested for by `pldm_msgbuf_init()` below, so no need to duplicate it here.
Updated.
I'm also concerning about "return rc;" without destroy buf. As you said it is better to call destroy before return. BUT it is unnecessary because return error is unexpected case and should be avoid.

> I'm also concerning about "return rc;" without destroy buf. As you said it is better to call destroy before return.

So there are no memory allocations involved in `pldm_msgbuf_init()` or `pldm_msgbuf_destroy()`. We're not leaking resources or anything, it's fine to just `return rc;`

`pldm_msgbuf_destroy()` invalidates the internal state so it is obvious if it's reused, but it also returns whether the buffer was in an invalid state (i.e. whether it prevented an out-of-bounds buffer access). Making `pldm_msgbuf_destroy()` return whether all accesses were valid or not allows us to batch that test when we don't care to use the values that were extracted.

In this case because we're testing `rc` we know whether an invalid access has occurred. Further, as the `struct pldm_msgbuf` object is stack-allocated it is immediately destroyed upon returning from the function.

> BUT it is unnecessary because return error is unexpected case and should be avoid.

We need to make sure we're accurate, but in some cases we can improve the readability of the code by batching the tests.
Why are you doing all this again?
I removed the duplicate code.
Nice, glad to see this used elsewhere!
Yes, It is nice when you already support that function.

Thus must be

```
    return pldm_msgbuf_destroy(buf);
```

This is required so the caller can determine whether the extraction was successful, which it may not have been due to buffer overflow.
Updated.
Perhaps instead of this we can use `struct pldm_msgbuf` to also extract the encoded values?
Yes, I updated the code to use extract functions.

Hi Thu, I have a problem with the decode API's handling of the `event_data` buffer. I don't think it's a particularly safe API, so I'm marking this as -1 for now. We can discuss how to fix it.

There's also an issue of trying to define a struct with a flexible array member that is not the last member of the struct. That must also be fixed.

Other than that I've tried to clarify where you do and don't need to check the return value of the `pldm_msgbuf_insert()` and `pldm_msgbuf_extract()` APIs. Checking their return value is only necessary if the following code dereferences the pointer under which the extracted value was placed. There's no need to check the return code if the pointer is not dereferenced, which helps improve readability.

Are you trying to put a flexible array in the middle of a struct definition? Because we really must not do that. Per the standard they must be the last member of a struct. Defining a flexible array member with a length of 1 is undefined behaviour, defining one in the middle of the struct is too much.

Either order `event_data_integrity_checksum` before `event_data` (the order of the members in the struct is less relevant now we use the msgbuf abstraction internally rather than casting packed structs), or remove `event_data_integrity_checksum` entirely.

Yes. I planed to create a flexible array in the middle of a struct definition. I based on the response data in DSP0248 of PollForPlatformEventMessage command to create the struct.
About moving event_data_integrity_checksum before event_data, I don't think it is reasonable we should not change the order of struct fields which reflect response data.

I thinks there are two options for this issue:
Option 1: Remove event_data_integrity_checksum fields (as your comment).
Option 2: I will removed this struct. We can do this because
1. After refactor the code to use msgbuf extract/insert we don't use type casting.
2. In the old code, this struct is packed structs and the response message is also packed data. If we change the struct to non-packed struct, we can't use type casting with response message payload. So removing this struct is reasonable.

Let discuss which option should we choose. I will chose option 1.

I'd prefer we do 2 and not add to the ABI surface of the library if we don't have to.

The struct definition can never be correct in its current form if `event_data_size` is greater than 1. We cannot add this struct in its current form.
Removed the added struct.

How do we know the caller-provided `event_data` buffer is large enough to contain the extracted event data? It must be at least `event_data_size`, but the caller doesn't know the value of `event_data_size` before calling the function.

Who is responsible for allocating the `event_data` buffer though? Is the only caller `libpldm` itself where we can guarantee it's the correct size? If so, why is this function part of the public API of the library? If not, and consumers of `libpldm` are expected to call the function, then you have to assume they will use it incorrectly. It doesn't do anything to mitigate failure to pay attention to the requirement.

Here's a good resource on API design - Rusty's API scale:

1. [How Do I Make This Hard to Misuse?](https://ozlabs.org/~rusty/index.cgi/tech/2008-03-30.html)
2. [What If I Don't Actually Like My Users?](https://ozlabs.org/~rusty/index.cgi/tech/2008-04-01.html)

I think at best this scores a `3. Read the documentation and you'll get it right.`

>    People only read instructions after they've already tied themselves into a knot. Then they skim them for keywords and don't read your warnings. I don't give an example of this; if this is the best an interface can get do, it's in trouble.

"after they've already tied themselves into a knot" in this case is the discovery of memory corruption at runtime, in which case they've already lost.

Let's figure out how to do better.

One approach would be to pass the size of the caller-provided buffer as an argument and not conflate that with `payload_size`.

Another option would be to pass a double pointer (`void **event_data`) and have the implementation heap-allocate the required space (`*event_data = malloc(event_data_size);`)
I updated the function to pass double point void **event_data to functions.
